captions.text:
I'm a big fan of yours. You're so fresh and
real, and I love how you manage to be fascinating

day in and day out! I'm particularly impressed
by your devotion to the laws of nature and

how you stick to them regardless of opinion
polls of scientists or the public. Of course,

our goal in science is to find out how you
work by careful observation. But it doesn't

matter at all if I believe in a theory or
not - what matters is whether you work that

way. A lot of popular ideas (like, "the earth
is flat") turned out to be wrong, and a lot

of uncomfortable ideas (like quantum mechanics,
evolution and plate tectonics) turned out

to be right. But I don't need to tell you
that, you know already - in fact, you set

the rules. It's a dictatorship, Universe:
you decide how you work, and I get no vote!

I would complain, except that I DO get to
decide where to stick my nose and which questions

to ask, and that's what makes science (and
life) fun. Plus, you're beautiful.

If you ever get this message, please let me
know by encoding your response in the digits
of pi. And thanks for being so incredible.
A collection of atoms known as Henry

comments.text: This is the future of prayer﻿

comments.author: Matthew Meinema

comments.text:
+Thiago Coelho Pi (or Tau, as I prefer) is involved any time you have a 
regular periodic signal or motion. Without the circle constant, you can't 
describe these phenomena mathematically. Hence, Pi, or Tau, is as real a 
thing as, say, 2. And in fact, both Pi and Tau are *real* numbers. :-)

+Agimaso Schandir The banana we have today is the result of extensive 
domestication and selective breeding efforts by humans - possible only due 
to reality of evolution. Hence, its use as an argument for creationism has 
given rise to the term 'banana logic': An argument which you think proves 
your point, but which in fact proves the opposite.

NO! You can't think about Evolution vs. Creationism as right and wrong. If 
you do, then you're just as pious as they are. Instead you should show them 
with hard evidence and facts that their THEORY is far, far LESS LIKELY then 
your theory. In Science there isn't any right and wrong so much as there is 
More Likely and Less Likely. If you can't explain your theory with facts 
and evidence than your theory is just as faith based as theirs is.

comments.author: Занудный Лис

comments.text:
In ASCII, the decimal point is coded by the number 010 1110, in essence 
your computer reads this number and a decimal point as the same. This 
number in base 10 is 46. Thus, the sequence 1465 is the same as 1.5, so 
yes, it is in pi.

comments.author: Joseph Greenburg

comments.text:
I am very sorry for the EXTREME delay, I completely forgot about our 
discussion and it is rude of me to keep you hanging, so I'll dive right 
into it.

1. Ok so you misunderstood me on point one, God is almighty and can do 
things beyond our comprehension, I did mean that he made the world fully 
developed, not a molten ball of rock with baby animals frying on it, and so 
since the world was created immediately of course radiometric dating would 
say it is billions of years old, it's not like He "skipped over" billions 
and billions of years of creation. He merely made them happen in an 
instant, same goes for the universe.  But you say they were both created at 
the same time, and that is true but once again the billions of years to 
create a universe will merely quickened and made to happen in an instance 
so that we had heavens to look upon.  Which, brings up an interesting 
point, how do you explain the origins of the universe? It could not be 
eternal, because as we all know the universe is not like God, it does not 
have infinite energy and therefore that theory goes against the second law 
of thermodynamics. (You may know it as "Entropy")  Now if you believe in 
"the big bang", I have done research and apparently it is more of a stretch 
from a single point in space, well this is basically throwing away the law 
of conservation of energy; energy cannot be destroyed nor created.  Now you 
might fight back saying God created energy but we know that God's power is 
endless and he can do all things.  If you say that the energy was already 
within that single point in space... then that's ridiculous! Where did that 
energy come from?  Was it there from the beginning? If so then that once 
again contradicts Entropy.

2.  Lucy is merely multiple bone fragments that were found somewhat near 
each other and then thrown together to create an ape-man.  In all the 
pictures, you can tell that the ribs do not line up and the bones are 
extremely fragmented and there are no feet.  Since the amount of bones is 
so extremely limited there is no way to know whether or not this is a 
possible link.  I could not find any proof whatsoever of the fossil types 
you listed so I’ll have to take your word for it, but still...  One fossil 
record each? Do you know how many fossil records we have of the rarest 
creatures on the planet? A lot more than one.  And the truth is, people 
want evolution to be right, that is why it is so openly accepted, because 
it destroys morals.  It proves that watching pornography, committing 
adultery, murder and all other sins are merely just primal instincts. 
 Another point, why are there laws? Why don’t we not just murder someone we 
don't like very much? Because we are descendants of God (not all of us as I 
will explain in the next section) and we know what is right and what is 
wrong.

4.  I am slightly unsure about your view of God.  God gives man the choice 
to accept and love God or ignore him and hate him.  God gives us evidence 
of him everywhere we go.  We have souls, you can’t deny it, you feel love, 
compassion and even sorrow for other humans; these feeling would not be 
possible if we were mechanical beings as evolution depicts us.  Because if 
we were we would still be animals, we would not know love, we would merely 
"mate" and fight with each other like bears for a mate and we would survive 
just for the sake of doing so.  I don't care how long you say it took to 
make an ape into a man.  You cannot turn an ape that can’t read or write 
into a man that can go to the moon and back, but most importantly, 
evolution cannot create a soul.

This is all I'm going to post for now, since I am busy with school starting 
and all.
comments.author: Joseph Greenburg

comments.text:
+Jake Whitton I'm the same as far as my religious beliefs go. I've always 
had problems with Gnosticism (including Gnostic atheism). Also, yes, I 
would agree that the crude approach can have its uses, but I find it's best 
to sway fence-sitters rather than theists. Anyway, carry on, Sir.
comments.author: Bryce Pantoja

comments.text:
+Bryce Pantoja Thank you :).  In some situations, the crude approach can be 
effective.  More often than not, people treat their religions as sacred and 
being off-limits from questioning and rational inquiry, in which case, all 
the rational arguments and rebuttals will do absolutely nothing.  I'm 
actually very happy to see a person who denies evolution for reasons that 
aren't dogmatic(at least in principle).  Also, I am an agnostic atheist, 
just to clarify. :)
comments.author: Jake Whitton

comments.text:
+Jake Whitton I'd like to thank you for your willingness to explain both 
Evolution by Means of Natural Selection and your rebuttals to Biblical 
Creationism in such detail to any out there willing to listen. Honestly, I 
was going to write up a response of my own, but after seeing that, I don't 
think I really have much to add on the subject. I get that dealing with the 
same arguments against evolution and for God can get very tedious for a lot 
of atheists (especially for those of us interested in trying to provide a 
clear and accurate picture of evolution and our beliefs - or, more 
accurately, our lack thereof), but it's great to see someone else who isn't 
just immediately and rudely dismissive of Creationist claims.

I think a lot of us have heard many of these arguments so many times that 
we start to think in-depth explanations have no effect. The important thing 
to remember, of course, is that each and every time we hear these 
arguments, they are coming from a different person, so in reality, we could 
be setting the path for them to critically look at their beliefs each and 
every time, but still get fed up because we feel as though we're not. This 
is especially true when it comes to people like Joseph Greenburg above, 
who, as you mentioned, seems to actually be willing to listen to arguments 
presented and attempt to rebut them, which is far better than the rhetoric 
we seem to get most of the time. 

P.S. Sorry if you're not an atheist. I don't mean to assume when (as far as 
I can tell) you've never outright stated that you are. Either way, it 
doesn't matter. I still appreciate you taking so much time to write such a 
coherent response. Also, this ended up being way longer than I originally 
anticipated, so sorry about that.
comments.author: Bryce Pantoja

comments.text:
+Joseph Greenburg I am grateful I am able to have this conversation with 
you.  It's not very often that I come across people with beliefs analogous 
to yours who are also willing to defend them rationally.  Much of your 
criticism is indeed valuable.  In trying to maintain brevity, I left out a 
lot of the meaningful explanation of those claims.  However, I'd like to 
address your defense of biblical creationism for now.  I'll address the 
rebuttal to the evidences of evolution later in this response.

A Note: This is a quite long response.  I apologize in advance.  I just 
want to seize the opportunity to pick your brain a little bit.

*ADDRESSING CLAIMS DEFENDING BIBLICAL CREATIONISM*:

1. *"With your point one you say that radiometric dating says the world is 
4.54 billion years old.  However, God is eternal and almighty, could he not 
create a mature heaven and earth?"* - If an omnipotent God did exist(a 
claim that has not yet been demonstrated), he would, undoubtedly, have the 
ability to create the heavens and the earth however he wished them to be. 
 I can only assume that, by "mature", you mean fully developed.  I could 
certainly be wrong, and please tell me if I am, but that's the way I 
interpreted your response.  If that is how you intended the word, then this 
response is rather irrelevant.  Modern science(the principles of 
radioactivity, measuring of half lives, etc.) has granted us a reliable way 
of dating fossils(really the rock around fossils); it is called Uranium-235 
dating.  Through dating the oldest rocks we have, we have determined the 
approximate age of the earth(~4.54 billion years).  We also have a method 
of dating stars that tells us, along with some of the math associated with 
General and Special relativity, we can determine the approximate age of the 
Universe to be ~13.7 billion years old.  Now, if God did create the 
Universe, he *could* have formed it mature(with all life, regions, etc.), 
but that isn't the issue we're dealing with.  We have some good models 
about how earth came about.  We know it wasn't just "created mature", 
because it was a very long and tedious process to create a planet capable 
of supporting some life some of the time.  From the science, we know that 
the "heavens and the earth" weren't created mature, so how is it not a 
contradiction when your Bible claims that it did?

2. *"With your point three you merely copied the same thing you mentioned 
in your prior point five. There are no records of fossil transitions and 
you can't prove it."* - I agree that the fossil record was used in as 
evidence both contradicting biblical creationism and supporting the Theory 
of Evolution by Means of Natural Selection.  I think that it's amazing we 
have the fossils that we do possess.  It is incredibly unlikely that any 
given organism who dies will become permanently frozen in the fossil 
record.  When an organism dies(in a natural way and is not purposefully 
preserved), it lays there, on the ground, rotting for a substantial amount 
of time.  It takes a tremendous amount of time for sediment to be deposited 
on top of a dead organism so that the micro-organisms will stop eating it. 
 Then, you have to survive millions or even billions of years being crushed 
by the rock above you, without losing your form.  Shortly said, it is 
incredibly unlikely that any given organism will be preserved long enough 
for us to observe it.  That being said, we have many transitional forms, 
even when it comes to the evolution of modern humans.  I think an 
acceptable point to start off with is *Australopithecus afarensis* this was 
a relatively early hominoid species that shared characteristics with both 
primitive apes and humans today.  The most common fossil of this species is 
known as "Lucy".  I urge you to look up a modern rendition of what Lucy may 
have looked like.  They did walk in a semi-bipedal way, but they still had 
the fur that is indicative of many apes you know today.  At this level, 
we're talking about hominoids(Superfamily Hominoidea).  Next, 
hominines(Family Hominidae) evolved.  Then, hominins(tribe Hominini) 
evolved.  Then, humans(Genus *Homo*) evolved.  I don't feel it's nessesary 
to cite evidence of this evolution, but, if requested, I will.  This 
paragraph is already quite lengthy, and I don't want to make you think I'm 
just using these Biological terms to "muddy up the waters".  Now, the first 
members of G. *Homo* were nothing like modern humans we see today.  In 
fact, one of the first species to evolve was *Homo habilis*.  If you look 
up a modern rendition of what it looks like, it is basically a a human with 
an ape's face and skin.  From here on, all the members of the genus *homo* 
are referred to as "humans".  From *Homo habilis*, we have the following 
progression of evolution(of which, all of them have at least 1 instance in 
the fossil record.), not all directly leading to *Homo sapiens*, but 
displaying the diversity of the genus *Homo*:
H. rudolfensis, H. georgicus, H. ergaster, H. erectus, H. cepranensis, H. 
antecessor, H. heidelbergensis, H. rhodesiensis, H. neanderthalensis, H. 
sapiens.  And, with all of that evolution, here we are today.  We can see 
the changes in various species of the genus *Homo*. over the last 2 million 
or so years that the genus *Homo* has existed.

3. *"Your point 4 is just a misinterpretation of the Bible.  In Genesis *
*1:27** the actual verse is "So God created man in His own image, in the 
image of God He created him; male and female He created them."  That does 
not say they were made simultaneously, merely that they were both created 
in God's image.  Furthermore, God did not seek out a partner for Adam, He 
created one."* - For brevity's sake, I'm going to give this one to you, for 
it's not really essential for my argument.  I'm no biblical scholar, nor do 
I claim to be one.  I can leave this one on the table for now.

4. *"And at last your point five.  God gave man free-choice and man chose 
to do wrong.  God is almighty but nevertheless He gave man the choice to do 
whatever he wanted.  Saying that we did nothing wrong is ridiculous! 
 Everyone has sinned and we must either pay for our sins ourselves, or 
accept Jesus' payment for our sins when He died on the cross."* - One of 
the properties of of the Judao-Christian God is omniscience.  Let's assume, 
for the sake of argument that God is indeed space-less, time-less, and 
transcendent, as many people put it.  He exists eternally, external to this 
Universe.  If we travel back in time to when God created the Universe, by 
his very own omniscience, will would have known every single thing that 
would happen in the future.  He knew what choices you were going to make, 
what life you were going to live, etc.  Now, let's say he then starts the 
Universe, and the 13.7 billion years passes, and you are born.  Then, 
today, you decide you're going to go out and eat some pizza with your 
friends at some restaurant.  When the waiter asks you what you want, you 
say, "one medium barbecue pizza".  You have, in that moment, made a 
"choice", facilitated by your free will.  Now, when God created the 
Universe, he knew that you were going to order a barbecue pizza.  If God 
had known that you would order a barbecue pizza, only then to learn that 
you actually ordered a vegetable pizza, that would count against God's 
omniscience.  In simple terms, you can *only* do what you were going to do. 
 If the future is determined in that way(we know it is determined, because, 
if otherwise, God wouldn't be able to know what kind of pizza you would 
order), you have no agency over which choice you make.  Essentially, God 
knows everything you will ever do, and you cannot do anything but what God 
knew in advance.  This position is known as "determinism".  Even without an 
omniscient God, free will seems to be a tricky thing to figure out.  If I 
extend this argument, without free will, why should we be punished for 
sinning?  We couldn't control sinning--it was in our very nature to sin. 
 If we had the free will to choose sin or grace, God shouldn't be able to 
know which choice we are going to make until we make it, thus counting 
against omniscience.

Phew.  That was a lot of text.  Congratulations on making it this far.  The 
evolutionary response will be more succinct. 

*ADDRESSING CLAIMS REBUTTING THE THEORY OF EVOLUTION BY MEANS OF NATURAL 
SELECTION*:

1. *"First off your point one and two are simple, saying that things have 
similar characteristics does not mean they are related, they merely have 
the practical anatomy to survive on the planet, you wouldn't say that a dog 
is related to a chair because they both have four legs, they just have four 
legs because it is required for stability.  The same goes for the anatomy 
of many animals, God wouldn't make the internal anatomy of a dolphin 
entirely different from a whale's just for the sake of them being 
different."* - I actually agree with this.  My first 2 points were poorly 
explained, and I apologize for that.  I will try to make up for that now. 
 To reiterate, my first two claims were that modern genetics and physiology 
support the Theory of Evolution by Means of Natural Selection.  This was 
poorly worded.  I pretended as if simply being similar meant you were 
related.  This is indeed wrong.  However, as I'll show in a second, you can 
use both modern genetics and physiology to demonstrate the related-ness of 
organisms.  Let's take the first example:
*Modern Genetics*: Within genetics, each organism has a genome--the 
collection of all the genetic information possessed by that organism. 
 Using the Theory of Evolution by Means of Natural Selection, you can make 
the prediction that, organisms that are distantly related, evolutionary 
speaking, will have much more differences between the genomes of both of 
them, as opposed to having two closely related animals, who will have 
little genetic differences.  This prediction is derived from the idea that 
organisms adapt by possessing beneficial mutations that aid them in 
surviving and/or reproduction.  If we extrapolate this, the more distantly 
related you are to an organism, the more mutations that would have happened 
between the two of you.  This prediction actually turns out to be true; in 
fact, modern humans and chimpanzees share about 90% of their DNA, where as 
humans and mice share about 80%.  It's only 10%, but it's actually quite 
significant, what with all 3 of these animals being mammals(who have only 
existed for ~4% of the time earth have existed, which is not a very long 
amount of time to evolve tremendous differences).  If God did create all 
animals spontaneously, why would he make it look like chimpanzees and 
humans are closely related if they weren't?

2. *"Your point three is confusing, because when I read this page I 
realized no evidence whatsoever was presented, I looked up the transitory 
whale and found nothing, if you want to talk about predictions and 
prophecies then the Bible has you beat before you even begin.  The Bible 
records many predictions that could not have been made by pure chance, 
though many have said the Bible has been edited and these passages have 
been added in a later edition of the Bible, countless repeated researches 
have shown this is wrong."* - Just to start off, I'd like some evidence of 
that last assertion.  It seems quite plausible that there were altercations 
to the bible(not to mention the plausibility that the story was completely 
fabricated), even the New Testament, considering that the earliest accounts 
of Jesus and his disciples date to about 90 C.E. with the John Rylands 
manuscript(the Oldest known New Testament manuscript).  That's 57 years 
after Jesus was suspected to have died, and this was the most optimistic 
estimate I could find.  Most historians place it around 150 C.E.  That 
seems like plenty of time for the game of telephone to have its affects. 
 Your example of a bible prophecy is interesting.  I've never heard that 
particular one.  I'll be the first to admit; I'm not educated on this 
example.  Thus, I don't have the ability to assess it's credibility.  That 
being said, is it possible that this could either have been a 
self-fulfilling prophecy or a fraudulent account?  It certainly wouldn't be 
the first time evidence was inserted into the bible after the fact.  The 
church perpetrated the "evidence of the historicity of Jesus" that was the 
account of Josephus, which was ultimately a forgery.  Why couldn't this be 
a similar case?

3. *"Your point number four is a very common mistake that evolutionists 
make, that is adaptation not evolution.  The same has happened with many 
creatures, they adapt to their surroundings.  Evolution is the transition 
between "Kinds" there are too many definitions of the word "species" for me 
to use it.  The only way you could convince me of this transition is if you 
showed me a long line of fossils turning an ape into a human (don't give me 
links and don't tell me any of that stuff, I know it isn't proven and it 
never will be.)  Now point number five is profound and extremely lacking of 
any evidence.  Colin Patterson a senior Paleontologist at the British 
Museum of Natural History, which houses sixty million specimens (the 
largest fossil collection in the world) confessed "If I knew of any 
evolutionary transitions, fossil or living, I would certainly have included 
them in my book 'Evolution'".  If that is not enough to convince you I have 
much more evidence that shows how wrong you are in believing there are many 
evolutionary transitions in the fossil records."* - firstly, even if Colin 
Patterson had said that and meant it(which he didn't; it was a quote mine), 
that would have no impact on the voracity of Evolution.  Evolution is true 
no matter what people say, because it's truth is determined by the evidence 
that supports it, not the people who advocate it.  As for the whole 
Micro-Evolution/Macro-Evolution ordeal, it's not even an argument.  The 
process of Macro-Evolution is the exact same process that Micro-Evolution 
is--adaptation.  The only difference is the time scales.  Take a look at my 
example of variation within the genus *Homo*.  Over many periods of 
Micro-Evolution(more erect stance, larger brain capacity, opposable thumbs, 
language "gene", etc), you get Macro-Evolution.  Micro-Evolution is the 
transition between *Homo Habilis* and *Homo Erectus*, and Macro-Evolution 
is the transition between *Homo Habilis* and *Homo Sapien*.  This is just 
semantics, because they are the same exact process.  If one exists, the 
other exists.  It's as simple as that.
comments.author: Jake Whitton

comments.text:
+Jake Whitton though your argument is well-presented it is still lacking in 
actual evidence and your argument against Christianity shows how little you 
know of it.  
Your section for Evolution-ism:
First off your point one and two are simple, saying that things have 
similar characteristics does not mean they are related, they merely have 
the practical anatomy to survive on the planet, you wouldn't say that a dog 
is related to a chair because they both have four legs, they just have four 
legs because it is required for stability.  The same goes for the anatomy 
of many animals, God wouldn't make the internal anatomy of a dolphin 
entirely different from a whale's just for the sake of them being 
different.  
Your point three is confusing, because when I read this page I realized no 
evidence whatsoever was presented, I looked up the transitory whale and 
found nothing, if you want to talk about predictions and prophecies then 
the Bible has you beat before you even begin.  The Bible records many 
predictions that could not have been made by pure chance, though many have 
said the Bible has been edited and these passages have been added in a 
later edition of the Bible, countless repeated researches have shown this 
is wrong.  The book of Daniel which was written before 530 B.C. predicts 
the progression of kingdoms from Babylon through the Medopersian Empire, 
the Greek Empire, and the Roman Empire, culminating in the persecution and 
suffering of the Jews under Antioches IV Epiphanes, his desecration of the 
temple, his untimely death, and freedom for the Jews under Judas Maccabeus 
which was all proven to happen in 165 B.C.  (If this argument continues I 
will show MANY more examples of proven prophesies if you wish) Your point 
number four is a very common mistake that evolutionists make, that is 
adaptation not evolution.  The same has happened with many creatures, they 
adapt to their surroundings.  Evolution is the transition between "Kinds" 
there are too many definitions of the word "species" for me to use it.  The 
only way you could convince me of this transition is if you showed me a 
long line of fossils turning an ape into a human (don't give me links and 
don't tell me any of that stuff, I know it isn't proven and it never will 
be.)  Now point number five is profound and extremely lacking of any 
evidence.  Colin Patterson a senior Paleontologist at the British Museum of 
Natural History, which houses sixty million specimens (the largest fossil 
collection in the world) confessed "If I knew of any evolutionary 
transitions, fossil or living, I would certainly have included them in my 
book 'Evolution'".  If that is not enough to convince you I have much more 
evidence that shows how wrong you are in believing there are many 
evolutionary transitions in the fossil records.  
Your section against Christianity:
In your point one you say that radiometric dating says the world is 4.54 
billion years old.  However, God is eternal and almighty, could He not 
create a mature heaven and earth? (That deals with your point two as well).
  With your point three you merely copied the same thing you mentioned in 
your prior point five. There are no records of fossil transitions and you 
can't prove it.  
Your point 4 is just a misinterpretation of the Bible.  In Genesis 1:27 the 
actual verse is "So God created man in His own image, in the image of God 
He created him; male and female He created them."  That does not say they 
were made simultaneously, merely that they were both created in God's 
image.  Furthermore, God did not seek out a partner for Adam, He created 
one.
  And at last your point five.  God gave man free-choice and man chose to 
do wrong.  God is almighty but nevertheless He gave man the choice to do 
whatever he wanted.  Saying that we did nothing wrong is ridiculous! 
 Everyone has sinned and we must either pay for our sins ourselves, or 
accept Jesus' payment for our sins when He died on the cross.

Please let us continue a civilized argument.
comments.author: Joseph Greenburg

comments.text:
+Joseph Greenburg Some evidence that supports the Theory of Evolution by 
Means of Natural Selection:
1. Modern genetics(we see similarities in the genome of species, implying 
we are related to them)
2. Physiological similarities between closely related groups of 
organisms(the bone structure of many of the mammals remains constant)
3. Valid predictions made by the theory(if we have a gap in the fossil 
record, we can predict the properties of that missing link).  This has been 
done NUMEROUS times.  Look here for more: 
http://answersinscience.org/evo_science.html
4. Observations of evolution in action(bacteria have developed antibiotic 
resistance, etc)
5. The existence of fossils that tell us the history of physiological 
changes of organisms over the entire history of the earth.

Some evidence that contradicts biblical creationism:
1.  Radiometric dating tells us that the earth is ~4.54 billion years old, 
which is inconsistent with the Genesis account.
2.  Using the dating of stars, we can say that the Universe is ~13.7 
billion years old.  This is inconsistent with the Genesis account(in 
Genesis 1:1, the "heavens" and the earth are created simultaneously).
3.  The fossil record shows a steady progression between pre-historic man 
and modern humans.  Nowhere in the fossil record do animals just "pop into 
existence".
4.  There are 2 contradicting accounts of creation(Genesis 1 and Genesis 
2).  In Genesis 2, Adam is created, then God tries to find a suitable 
partner for Adam, leading to Eve(Gensis 2:18).  In Genesis 1, Adam and Eve 
are created simultaneously(Genesis 1:27).
5.  The idea that an omniscient God would allow the tree of knowledge to 
exist in the garden, knowing full well that Adam and Eve were going to 
disobey them, only to then punish them and all their descendants(who did 
NOTHING wrong) to hell if they don't love him enough is absolutely absurd.

Please, tell me why this evidence is insufficient or inaccurate.  I would 
love to hear you defend such a sloppy idea as biblical creationism.  That 
would be quite a feat.
comments.author: Jake Whitton

comments.text:
As much as we romanticize the universe, don't forget that it's actually 
unsparingly cruel. Leave the confines of earth for a second and you'll die 
in the vacuum of space.
Black holes, massive suns, galaxies moving rapidly towards ours, the 'big 
freeze' (in which things move so far away from each other that they start 
to freeze up) and comets are all very real prospects... oh and the higgs 
field was calculated to have an ultra-dense state, meaning that life would 
be impossible. It's completely unpredictable when this will happen and if, 
but it could theoretically happen.
The universe, in all its beauty, is very unforgiving!﻿

the numerator's place. Because of this, the numerator will always be one 
less than the denominator, thus no decimal could ever be equal to one.

comments.author: Jesse Davis

comments.text:
By definition, infinity is not a number, and therefore 1/infinity is not a 
number.
You cannot say it's "the smallest number ever" if its not even a number.
The closest identity to what we're talking about here is the Limit as 
x->infinity of 1/x. This is equal to a number; 0. Just 0.

With that knowledge you should now be able to convince yourself that 
.999... is identical to 1.
comments.author: cre2per

comments.text:
+cre2per I know it does not, however by the definition of infinity 
1/infinity would be the smallest number ever. An infinitely small number, I 
was using that to represent that 0.999... is not 1.

...
8 / 9 = 0.8...
9 / 9 = 0.9... = 1

comments.text:
+Math Pro Well, depends what you mean by "random."  It certainly *appears* 
random to a person.  An interesting question: is it "typical" or 
"extraordinary" for an irrational number to have this property that it 
contains every possible finite sequence within its digits?  Yet another 
question: if an irrational number has this property in one base (e.g. base 
10) then does it have this property in any other base (e.g. base 2)?  Yet 
yet another question: does this property depend on whether the number is 
algebraic or transcendental?  Can anyone see a proof that my number in the 
previous post is algebraic, or transcendental?  Number theorists, please 
help!
comments.author: Arephid1

comments.text:
There are irrational numbers which fail to have a given message.  For 
example, the number 1.01001000100001000001... is irrational (doesn't repeat 
anything infinitely) but it doesn't contain any meaningful message.

comments.text:
The laws of physics refers to the truly basic laws. God operates within 
them, by definition. If He made the universe act a certain way, those are 
not the laws of physics, just like how if you program a computer a certain 
way, the program is not the laws of physics, and the computer is 
fundamentally running on the actual laws of physics.
comments.author: Daniel Carrier

comments.text:
Why did you post that original comment? I was guessing you meant something 
like that, since it would violate the spirit of my comment, if not strictly 
speaking contradict it. As is, it looks like you just mentioned something 
fairly unrelated. The fact that you can't perfectly represent pi in binary 
has nothing to do with the fact that the universe can't encode a response 
in the digits of pi.
comments.author: Daniel Carrier

comments.text:
"Any computer representation will always have a minimum, definable error" = 
L/2 where L is equal to the value of the LSB. Actually, for any particular 
representation, the error might be less, but at most all you can say for 
any arbitrary estimate, E, is that the actual value is between E+L/2 and 
E-L/2. I made no comment in regard to any hypothetical alternate universe.
comments.author: inyobill

comments.text:
It will always have an error, but there's no minimum error. Every 
additional bit cuts the error in half. Furthermore, this error is something 
mathematical. It's not going to be different in a different universe.

comments.author: Akash K

comments.text:
As a Christian I'm supposed to believe one thing about evolution. It's 
bull. But as I've grown less ignorant of my surroundings I've found that 
through my free will I have been granted the ability to understand things. 
This open mind acquisition has led to the acceptance of evolution while 
still retaining my faith. In in way is my goal to upset any of my 
religion's followers, its merely to create a bond between us all, keep 
faith in your heart but if 2+2 equals 4 well.. Accept it.
comments.author: David Garcia

comments.text:
Pi is a mathematical constant. The universe can't change it. The best it 
can do is cause errors in your computer so it miscalculates it in a certain 
way. You need a unit-less physical constant, like the fine structure 
constant.
comments.author: Daniel Carrier

comments.text:
Dear universe. You suck. I understand that sticking to your principles 
makes neat things happen, but you don't have to do it all the time. Your 
laws of thermodynamics have caused millions to starve to death. And your 
general lack of making sure bad things don't happen has resulted in 
horrifying things, like entire species that survive only by killing and 
eating other species. If you get this message, please reply by making all 
the really bad stuff stop happening.
comments.author: Daniel Carrier
